title: Power - resistors X and Y have same current

content.question: Two resistors, Resistor <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> and Resistor <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math>, have the same current but different resistances. Resistor <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> has a resistance <math alttext="R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> and dissipates an amount of power <math alttext="P sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math>, and Resistor <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> has a resistance <math alttext="4 R sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math> and dissipates an amount of power <math alttext="P sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub></math>. What is the ratio <math alttext="P sub Y to P sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mi>P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></msub></math>?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
